G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19, 19A..proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds the minimum jurisdictional requirements of this Court for a civil action and is within the monetary jurisdiction of the Worcester District Court, G.L. c. 218, §§ 19, 19A.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 2 and G.L. c. 223, § 3 because the causes of action arose in Worcester, Massachusetts and the Property and accident at issue are located in Worcester.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 3.proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 2 and G.L. c. 223, § 3 because the causes of action arose in Worcester, Massachusetts and the Property and accident at issue are located in Worcester.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707\.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or person in control of premises owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors, including invitees such as delivery persons, to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances. *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707–08 (1973).
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707\.support_reasoning: The quoted passage is from a concurrence and focuses on criticizing continued use of the trespasser category, but it presupposes and is consistent with the majority’s central move in Mounsey: abandoning rigid invitee/licensee distinctions in favor of a general duty of reasonable care to lawful entrants. The specific proposition—that Massachusetts occupiers owe a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors, including invitees such as delivery persons—is grounded in the majority opinion at 363 Mass. 707–08, not in this concurrence excerpt, but the concurrence does not contradict it and implicitly accepts that broader duty. Because we do not see the majority text itself here, support is assessed as medium rather than high confidence.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707\.relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors.

*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.proposition: This duty includes a duty to act as a reasonably prudent person would under the circumstances to discover and remedy dangerous conditions that the owner knows or reasonably should know about, and to warn lawful visitors of such conditions when they cannot be made safe. *Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739, 743–44 (1995); *Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co.*, 400 Mass. 837, 842 (1987).
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the general premises-liability duty of a landowner to lawful visitors and describes it in terms that match the proposition: a duty of reasonable care that includes maintaining the premises in reasonably safe condition and warning of unreasonable dangers the owner knows or should know about. Although the case ultimately holds there was no duty regarding alterations to an adjacent state highway, its articulation of the landowner’s basic duty directly supports the quoted proposition. The citation is therefore appropriate for that general duty rule.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors… This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware. Thorson v. Mandell… Toubiana v. Priestly… Polak v. Whitney… Although a landowner or possessor typically is not held to any duty with respect to public highways adjacent to or crossing his land…” (420 Mass. at 743).

*Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co.*, 400 M.proposition: This duty includes a duty to act as a reasonably prudent person would under the circumstances to discover and remedy dangerous conditions that the owner knows or reasonably should know about, and to warn lawful visitors of such conditions when they cannot be made safe. *Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739, 743–44 (1995); *Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co.*, 400 Mass. 837, 842 (1987).
*Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co.*, 400 M.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Young (a concurring opinion) addresses the absence of a duty to warn of an obvious risk (negligent operation of other vehicles at a gas station), not the general duty of a landowner to act reasonably to discover, remedy, and warn of dangerous conditions. It actually limits duty by stating there is no duty to warn of an inherent and obvious danger, rather than articulating the broader affirmative duty described in the proposition. Thus it does not support the specific proposition cited.
*Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co.*, 400 M.relevant_excerpt: "In my view, the risk of injury to a customer from the negligent operation of another vehicle on the premises of a self-service station is inherent and obvious. There is no duty to warn of such a danger."

*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.proposition: Defendant, as the owner and person in control of 45 Elm Street and the adjacent sidewalk used as access to the Property, owed Plaintiff a duty of reasonable care to keep the sidewalk and means of ingress and egress in a reasonably safe condition, to remove or treat snow and ice accumulations within a reasonable time, and to warn reasonable foreseeable visitors of any dangerous conditions. *Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 152–53 (2013); *Barry v. Beverly Enters.-Mass., Inc.*, 418 Mass. 590, 592–93 (1994).
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a landowner’s duty regarding snow, ice, and the safety of sidewalks and means of ingress/egress. Dos Santos deals with a residential landlord’s duty concerning an open and obvious danger created by placing a trampoline adjacent to a shallow pool, and the circumstances under which a landowner must remedy such an open and obvious condition. It does not address snow and ice removal, sidewalks, or ingress/egress duties, so it does not support the specific proposition stated (though it does discuss the general duty to maintain property in a reasonably safe condition).
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. … This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … It also includes an obligation ‘to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.’” (465 Mass. at 154).

*Barry v. Beverly Enters.-Mass., Inc.*,.proposition: Defendant, as the owner and person in control of 45 Elm Street and the adjacent sidewalk used as access to the Property, owed Plaintiff a duty of reasonable care to keep the sidewalk and means of ingress and egress in a reasonably safe condition, to remove or treat snow and ice accumulations within a reasonable time, and to warn reasonable foreseeable visitors of any dangerous conditions. *Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 152–53 (2013); *Barry v. Beverly Enters.-Mass., Inc.*, 418 Mass. 590, 592–93 (1994).
*Barry v. Beverly Enters.-Mass., Inc.*,.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the general premises-liability duty of a landowner to maintain property in a reasonably safe condition, but it does not specifically address or articulate a special duty regarding sidewalks or means of ingress/egress, nor a specific obligation to remove or treat snow and ice within a reasonable time and to warn visitors. Instead, the case turns on lack of actual or constructive notice of the icy condition and ultimately finds no breach of duty on those facts. Thus, it provides only a generic duty-of-care statement and does not clearly support the more detailed proposition as framed.
*Barry v. Beverly Enters.-Mass., Inc.*,.relevant_excerpt: “The law imposes on a property owner ‘a duty to maintain his property “in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.”’ … Thus, a defendant who did not have a reasonable opportunity to discover and remedy a hazardous condition — that is, a defendant who had no actual or constructive knowledge of the allegedly hazardous condition so that it could not reasonably remove, or warn the plaintiff of, the danger — cannot be found to have violated its duty of care.”

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: Since *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass. 368 (2010), Massachusetts law applies the same reasonable care standard to the removal of snow and ice as it does to other hazards, without distinction between “natural” and “unnatural” accumulations. Property owners must act reasonably under the circumstances to prevent injuries from snow and ice. *Papadopoulos*, 457 Mass. at 383–84.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that Massachusetts is abolishing the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction and replacing it with the ordinary reasonable care standard for all snow and ice hazards. It explicitly states that hazards from snow and ice are subject to the same duty of reasonable care owed for other premises hazards, and explains that factfinders must evaluate reasonableness under the circumstances rather than the nature of the accumulation, matching the proposition. The cited pages (around 383–84) contain this holding and its explanation.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’ … Under this traditional premises liability standard, a fact finder will determine what snow and ice removal efforts are reasonable in light of the expense they impose on the landowner and the probability and seriousness of the foreseeable harm to others.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Defendant’s duty is further informed by G.L. c. 231, § 85, which establishes comparative negligence principles but does not diminish Defendant’s primary duty of reasonable care to lawful visitors, and by G.L. c. 84, §§ 15–18, which, while directed primarily at municipal liability for defects in public ways, reflect a public policy that ways used by the public should be maintained in reasonably safe condition.

G.L. c. 84, \u00a7\u00a7 15\u201318.proposition: Defendant’s duty is further informed by G.L. c. 231, § 85, which establishes comparative negligence principles but does not diminish Defendant’s primary duty of reasonable care to lawful visitors, and by G.L. c. 84, §§ 15–18, which, while directed primarily at municipal liability for defects in public ways, reflect a public policy that ways used by the public should be maintained in reasonably safe condition.

*Gill v. Boston Post Rd. Dev. Corp.*, 10.raw_text: *Gill v. Boston Post Rd. Dev. Corp.*, 10 Mass. App. Ct. 895, 895–96 (1980)
*Gill v. Boston Post Rd. Dev. Corp.*, 10.proposition: Defendant’s knowledge of the dangerous icy condition is established by the prior complaints and photographs sent by tenants, which constitute actual notice. See *Gill v. Boston Post Rd. Dev. Corp.*, 10 Mass. App. Ct. 895, 895–96 (1980) (actual or constructive notice of hazardous condition required for premises liability).
*Gill v. Boston Post Rd. Dev. Corp.*, 10.case_name: Mikolinski v. Burt Reynolds Production Co.
*Gill v. Boston Post Rd. Dev. Corp.*, 10.support_reasoning: The provided opinion involves defamation and group libel, not premises liability or icy conditions. It does not discuss actual or constructive notice of a hazardous condition, tenant complaints, or photographs, so it cannot support the claimed proposition about actual notice of an icy condition. The citation appears to be entirely inapposite to the stated legal proposition.
*Gill v. Boston Post Rd. Dev. Corp.*, 10.relevant_excerpt: The judge did not err in allowing the defendants’ motion to dismiss the complaint. Although there appear to be no Massachusetts cases on the point, the judge followed the overwhelming weight of authority in ruling that the defendants’ alleged defamation of persons of Polish descent in the movie “The End” did not give rise to a civil cause of action by the individual plaintiff, who is of that national derivation.

*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.raw_text: *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.*, 448 Mass. 780, 784–85 (2007)
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.proposition: Even apart from actual notice, Defendant had constructive notice of the hazard because the dangerous condition existed for a sufficient period of time after the storm and through repeated melt‑and‑refreeze cycles that a reasonably careful owner would have discovered and corrected it. *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.*, 448 Mass. 780, 784–85 (2007); *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973).
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.support_reasoning: Sheehan concerns slip-and-fall liability inside a self-service grocery store and adopts the mode-of-operation doctrine to relax the traditional requirement of proving actual or constructive notice of a transitory hazard on the floor. It does not address hazards created by accumulated snow/ice, the passage of time after a storm, or melt‑refreeze cycles, nor does it discuss constructive notice based on the duration of an outdoor weather-related condition. Using Sheehan to support a proposition about constructive notice from long‑existing post‑storm ice conditions therefore mischaracterizes the case’s holding and context.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.relevant_excerpt: “Historically, Massachusetts has also followed the traditional approach governing premises liability… This court has thus held that premises liability attaches only if a store owner has actual or constructive notice of the existence of the dangerous condition, sufficient to allow time for the owner to remedy the condition… Of the two modern approaches, the mode of operation and burden-shifting approaches, the mode of operation approach is in our view the more preferable, and we now adopt it.”

*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.raw_text: *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973)
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.proposition: Even apart from actual notice, Defendant had constructive notice of the hazard because the dangerous condition existed for a sufficient period of time after the storm and through repeated melt‑and‑refreeze cycles that a reasonably careful owner would have discovered and corrected it. *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.*, 448 Mass. 780, 784–85 (2007); *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973).
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.support_reasoning: Oliveri discusses when constructive notice of a transient hazard can be inferred, but it ultimately holds that the plaintiff’s circumstantial evidence was *insufficient* to show the condition existed long enough for the defendant to discover and remedy it. The opinion does not involve a post-storm, melt-and-refreeze situation, and it concludes that a directed verdict for the defendant was required because the time element was not established. Thus, it does not support the proposition that constructive notice existed under extended, repeated melt–refreeze conditions; if anything, it is more defense‑oriented on the notice issue.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.relevant_excerpt: The issue presented is whether the evidence is sufficient to permit a jury to infer that the substance had been on the step long enough so that in the exercise of reasonable care the defendant should have discovered and removed it. ... There is nothing to distinguish this case from the great majority of cases in which we have held that directed verdicts were required. The mere stickiness or adherence of the substance to the step is not such a quality as, in common knowledge, established the time element.

*Jerlun, Inc. v. Broderick*, 458 Mass. 2.proposition: The type of harm suffered by Plaintiff—slipping on an icy surface and sustaining a back injury—is a foreseeable consequence of failing to exercise reasonable care in the treatment of snow and ice on a walkway. *Papadopoulos*, 457 Mass. at 383–84; *Jerlun, Inc. v. Broderick*, 458 Mass. 295, 303–04 (2010).
*Jerlun, Inc. v. Broderick*, 458 Mass. 2.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns suppression of evidence based on lack of voluntary consent to a dorm-room search and does not address premises liability, snow and ice, foreseeability of slip-and-fall injuries, or any related tort concepts. Nothing in the reasoning or holding discusses the type of harm at issue in the claimed proposition, so the case cannot serve as authority for foreseeability of injury from untreated snow and ice on a walkway.
*Jerlun, Inc. v. Broderick*, 458 Mass. 2.relevant_excerpt: We conclude that the judge did not err in finding that the Commonwealth failed to satisfy its burden of proving the voluntary consent of the defendants to search their room. We affirm. Because the drugs and other evidence will be suppressed, we need not decide whether the initial entry into the room was lawful.

*Griffiths v. Powers*, 10 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: As a further direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff missed approximately one week of work and incurred lost wages in the approximate amount of $1,000. See *Griffiths v. Powers*, 10 Mass. App. Ct. 899, 899–900 (1980) (lost wages recoverable as an element of damages in negligence).

*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover compensatory damages for medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life, and all other damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence. *Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540, 548–49 (1982); *Warren v. Ballard*, 134 Mass. 208, 209 (1883).
*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.support_reasoning: Payton is an opinion about Massachusetts tort doctrine on negligent infliction of emotional distress, prenatal injury, wrongful life, and market‑share liability. It does not address, list, or define the elements or categories of recoverable compensatory damages such as medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, or loss of enjoyment of life. Nothing in the cited pages (or elsewhere) states the broad damages rule asserted in the proposition, so Payton does not support that specific damages proposition, even though it recognizes a right of action for certain injuries.
*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.relevant_excerpt: "In summary, we hold that a plaintiff who alleges that she suffered injury in utero as a result of her mother's ingestion of a drug and that, but for the defendant's negligence, her mother would not have ingested that drug, has stated a claim upon which relief can be granted under Massachusetts law." (386 Mass. at 562–63). [No passage in Payton discusses or itemizes recoverable categories of compensatory damages.】

*Warren v. Ballard*, 134 Mass. 208, 209.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover compensatory damages for medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life, and all other damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence. *Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540, 548–49 (1982); *Warren v. Ballard*, 134 Mass. 208, 209 (1883).

*Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass.raw_text: *Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass’n, Inc.*, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 333, 337–38 (2010)
*Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass.proposition: Plaintiff was walking in a normal, reasonable manner on the only apparent and intended path provided by Defendant, and there was no open and obvious alternative safe route. Under Massachusetts law, the alleged “open and obvious” nature of a condition does not eliminate a landowner’s duty when the owner should anticipate that lawful entrants will nonetheless encounter the danger. *Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass’n, Inc.*, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 333, 337–38 (2010); *Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. at 156–57.
*Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass.case_name: Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condominium Association
*Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that the open and obvious nature of an ice condition on a known path of travel does not negate a landowner’s duty to remedy the hazard, but instead goes to comparative negligence. While the facts do not hinge on the plaintiff having absolutely no alternative route (the court rejects the trial judge’s ‘reasonable alternative’ threshold as a duty question), the case clearly adopts Restatement § 343A comment f and emphasizes that owners must anticipate that lawful entrants will still encounter open and obvious dangers in customary paths of travel. Thus it supports the proposition’s Massachusetts-law duty principle, even if it slightly overstates the ‘no alternative route’ factual aspect.
*Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass.relevant_excerpt: “No reported Massachusetts case has held that the obviousness of the dangers posed by the hazards of an unnatural accumulation of snow or ice negates an owner’s duty to remedy the hazard. … The Restatement recognizes that a property owner or possessor should not be relieved from remedying open and obvious dangers where he ‘can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the invitee notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.’ … we conclude that the open and obvious danger rule does not operate to negate a landowner’s duty to remedy hazardous conditions… where, as here, those hazards lie in a known path of travel.”

*Sullivan v. Brookline*, 416 Mass. 825,.proposition: Defendant’s conduct fell below the standard of care required by Massachusetts law and constituted negligence. *Papadopoulos*, 457 Mass. at 383–84; *Sullivan v. Brookline*, 416 Mass. 825, 828–29 (1994) (duty to use reasonable care in snow and ice removal); *Alter v. Newton*, 35 Mass. App. Ct. 142, 146–47 (1993).
*Sullivan v. Brookline*, 416 Mass. 825,.support_reasoning: The proposition cites Sullivan as authority for a general duty to use reasonable care in snow and ice removal and for conduct falling below the standard of care. In Sullivan, the SJC held the opposite: that a property owner has no duty to remove or sand a natural accumulation of snow and ice, and it reversed a plaintiff’s verdict for insufficient evidence of negligence. The case thus constrains, rather than supports, a claim that failure to remove/sand naturally accumulated ice is negligent under Massachusetts law.
*Sullivan v. Brookline*, 416 Mass. 825,.relevant_excerpt: “The duty owed by a property owner to someone lawfully on the owner’s premises is one of reasonable care in the circumstances…. In our most recent decision addressing an owner’s duty with regard to snow and ice, we made clear that this duty is not violated by a failure to remove a natural accumulation of snow or ice.… [T]here can be no liability because, as was said in Aylward, supra at 79, ‘naturally accumulated snow and ice on property does not per se constitute a defective condition.’… [J]udgment for the town was required.”

*Alter v. Newton*, 35 Mass. App. Ct. 142.proposition: Defendant’s conduct fell below the standard of care required by Massachusetts law and constituted negligence. *Papadopoulos*, 457 Mass. at 383–84; *Sullivan v. Brookline*, 416 Mass. 825, 828–29 (1994) (duty to use reasonable care in snow and ice removal); *Alter v. Newton*, 35 Mass. App. Ct. 142, 146–47 (1993).
*Alter v. Newton*, 35 Mass. App. Ct. 142.support_reasoning: The opinion recognizes and applies a negligence standard of reasonable care owed by a school (the City) to its student and upholds a jury verdict finding the City negligent for failing to take reasonable precautions (warnings, repositioning the net, etc.). The court explicitly states the City had a duty to provide reasonably safe school premises and concludes there was sufficient evidence of negligence outside the discretionary function immunity. Thus, it supports the use of Alter as authority that such conduct can fall below the Massachusetts standard of care and constitute negligence.
*Alter v. Newton*, 35 Mass. App. Ct. 142.relevant_excerpt: Because of the relationship between a school and its students, the city had a duty of care to the plaintiff to provide her with reasonably safe school premises. … Accordingly, unless each of the failures alleged by the plaintiffs fell within the discretionary function exception, or, unless the city showed a policy reason for not choosing any means to protect its students, the city would not have been entitled to summary judgment. … Since there was evidence that the city was negligent in failing to warn and in failing to reposition the lacrosse net… the city was not entitled to a directed verdict….

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre‑judgment and post‑judgment interest as allowed by law, including but not limited to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

G.L. c. 261.proposition: Costs of this action, including allowable fees and expenses, pursuant to G.L. c. 261 and other applicable law;

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 60 and the Massachusetts Rules of Civil Procedure, Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
